hints.Process Engineering: The design, operation, control, and optimization of chemical, physical, and biological processes.
hints.Systems Engineering: An interdisciplinary field of engineering that focuses on how to design and manage complex systems over their life cycles.
hints.Operations Research: The use of mathematical models, statistics and algorithms to help make better decisions.
hints.Quality Control: The process of detecting mistakes in operational outputs and correcting them.
hints.Ergonomics: The study of designing equipment and devices that fit the human body, its movements, and its cognitive abilities.
hints.Facility Layout: The arrangement of physical machines and spaces to optimize efficiency.
hints.Lean Manufacturing: A systematic method for waste minimization within a manufacturing system without sacrificing productivity.
hints.Six Sigma: A set of techniques and tools for process improvement, aiming to reduce defects and variability.
hints.Supply Chain Management: The management of the flow of goods and services, including all processes that transform raw materials into final products.
hints.Inventory Management: The supervision of non-capitalized assets, inventory, and stock items.
hints.Project Management: The practice of initiating, planning, executing, controlling, and closing the work of a team to achieve specific goals and meet specific success criteria.
hints.Time and Motion Study: The business efficiency technique combining the Time Study work of Frederick Winslow Taylor with the Motion Study work of Frank and Lillian Gilbreth.
hints.Simulation: The imitation of the operation of a real-world process or system over time.
hints.Production Planning: The planning of production and manufacturing modules in a company or industry.
hints.Work Measurement: The application of techniques designed to establish the time for a qualified worker to carry out a specified job at a defined level of performance.
